data.scheme_name:
Existing - 33Ab: Tea Development Account, Coffee Development Account And Rubber Development Account
10(30): Tea Board Subsidy 10(31) Other Subsidies
data.benefits: If you are running a business that deals with the manufacturing or cultivation of tea, coffee, or rubber, you are eligible for tax deduction upto 40%, provided you deposit a certain amount in the specified account.
data.eligibility: An entity engaged in growing and manufacturing of tea or coffee or rubber in India is eligible for claiming deduction under Section 33Ab, 10(30) and 10(31).
data.conditions:
1. You can avail of the deduction under Section 33AB of the Income Tax Act, 1961, only if a Chartered Accountant audits your books within a specified date.
  2.  You need to obtain the audit report from the Chartered Accountant in a prescribed form (Form 3AC). 
  3. If the books are already audited under any law, there is no need for a separate audit for Section 33AB of the Income Tax Act, 1961. 
  4. However, ensure that you furnish the audit report from the Chartered Accountant in Form 3C.
  5.  The amount deposited in the specified ‘special account’ or the ‘deposit account’ must be used per the scheme of the Tea Board, Coffee Board, or Rubber Board. 
  6. However, the utilized amount from the specified ‘special account’ or the ‘deposit account’ is not considered an expenditure while computing the profit from your business under the head ‘Profits and gains of business or profession.
data.beneficiaries: An entity engaged in growing and manufacturing of tea or coffee or rubber in India is eligible for claiming deduction under Section 33Ab, 10(30) and 10(31).
data.prerequisites:
1. You can avail of the deduction under Section 33AB of the Income Tax Act, 1961, only if a Chartered Accountant audits your books within a specified date.
  2.  You need to obtain the audit report from the Chartered Accountant in a prescribed form (Form 3AC). 
  3. If the books are already audited under any law, there is no need for a separate audit for Section 33AB of the Income Tax Act, 1961. 
  4. However, ensure that you furnish the audit report from the Chartered Accountant in Form 3C.
  5.  The amount deposited in the specified ‘special account’ or the ‘deposit account’ must be used per the scheme of the Tea Board, Coffee Board, or Rubber Board. 
  6. However, the utilized amount from the specified ‘special account’ or the ‘deposit account’ is not considered an expenditure while computing the profit from your business under the head ‘Profits and gains of business or profession.
data.description:
1. If you are running a business that deals with the manufacturing or cultivation of tea, coffee, or rubber, you are eligible for tax deduction, provided you deposit a certain amount in the specified account as mentioned under section 33AB.
  2.  Composite agriculture income rule - 60%-40%; Income which is partially agricultural and partially from business - the income earned from agricultural sources is exempt. 
  3. Income from the manufacture of rubber - the hybrid income earned from rubber industry and any other business shall be taxed only for 35% of total income . balance considered as agriculture income. 
  4. Income from the manufacture and cured of coffee - the hybrid income earned from coffee industry and any other business shall be taxed only for 25% of total income Income from the manufacture and cured and roasted of coffee - the hybrid income earned from coffee industry and any other business shall be taxed only or 40% of total income Income from the manufacture of tea - the hybrid income earned from tea industry and any other business shall be taxed only for 40% of total income Section – 33AB : (tea development account, coffee development account and rubber development account) 
  5. Lower of the following amount is allowed as a deduction:– the amount deposited in tea development account; or 40% of the profit computed under the head ‘profits and gains of business or profession’(before this deduction). 
  6. Section 10(30): (tea board subsidy) Any amount received from or through the tea board as subsidy shall be fully exempted. 
  7. Section 10(31) : (other subsidies) Any amount received from or through the concerned board as subsidy shall be fully exempted.
data.how_to_apply: Claim by filing Income Tax Return
data.funding_mechanism: Claim by filing Income Tax Return .Opt in required by assessee- Yes
data.additional_info:
Circumstances under which the withdrawal will be deemed to be income and taxed accordingly- under the following cases, any amount withdrawn from the deposit/ special account will be charged to income tax under the head ‘profits and gains of business or profession’- 

1. When the amount utilized for the purchase of- 

A. Plant/ machinery which is to be installed in office premises or residential accommodation (including guest house), 

B. Office appliances (other than computers). 

C. Plant/ machinery, wherein, the actual cost is allowed as a deduction under ‘profit and gains of business or profession’. 

D. Plant/ machinery which is to be installed in an industrial undertaking for the purpose of the business of manufacture, construction or production of any article/ thing specified in the eleventh schedule. 

2. When the amount is withdrawn either on the closure of the business or dissolution of the firm. 

3. When the amount is withdrawn for an approved specified purpose. However, the whole or part of the amount is not utilized within the end of the relevant previous year. 

4. When the asset acquired as per the scheme is sold/ transferred before the expiry of eight years from the end of the previous year in which the asset was acquired. However, sale/ transfer in the following circumstances are exempted- 

A. The asset is sold/ transferred to government or a local authority or a corporation or a government company; or 

B. Sale/ transfer on account of the succession of a firm by a company. Wherein, the applicability of scheme continues with the company. Let us understand this with an example. Let us say you deposited ₹ 1,20,000 in the ‘special account’ you maintain with NABARD (National Bank for Agriculture and Rural Development).
